title: 111_hr2601
content: The "Supporting Emergency Responders Volunteer Efforts Act of 2009" or the "SERVE Act of 2009" establishes a refundable credit for bona fide volunteer members of volunteer emergency response organizations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "SERVE Act of 2009" establishes a $1,000 tax credit for individuals who are bona fide volunteer members of qualified volunteer emergency response organizations. Compensation for services must be in the form of reasonable expenses or benefits. The "SERVE Act of 2009" establishes a $1,000 tax credit for volunteers in qualified emergency response organizations. Compensation must be reasonable benefits and nominal fees, not exceeding the annual limitation based on minimum wage and hours worked. The "SERVE Act of 2009" provides a $1,000 tax credit for volunteers in qualified emergency response organizations. To qualify, volunteers must serve for more than 6 months and provide over 40 hours of service in a taxable year. Training and certification requirements must also be met, and amounts excluded from gross income under section 139B are not considered for the tax credit. The "SERVE Act of 2009" offers a $1,000 tax credit for volunteers in qualified emergency response organizations who meet specific service and training requirements. The definition of qualified services includes fire fighting, emergency medical, and ambulance services. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "SERVE Act of 2009" provides a $1,000 tax credit for volunteers in emergency response organizations. Section 36B applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
